src: ɪ-n-gwina n=ɪ-n-gambɪlɪ ba-a-lɪ bʊ-manyaani fiijo a-ka-balɪlo a-k-a ijolo
trs: \lq Monkey and Crocodile were good friends long ago.
\lq They visited and accompanied each other.

src: ɪ-n-gwina j-iis-aga n-kʊ-j-eega ɪ-n-gambɪlɪ n=ʊ-kʊ-bʊʊk-a na=jo pa-lʊ-sʊngo pa-kw-angal-a
trs: \lq Crocodile used to come to pick up Monkey and go with him to an island to spend time together.

src: ii-sikʊ lɪ-mo ʊ-n-na gw-a n-gwina a-a-lɪ m̩-bine
trs: \lq One day Crocodile's mother was sick.
\lq Monkey agreed.

src: bo j-iitog-ile pa-mwanya pa-n-gwina ʊ-kʊ-bʊʊk-a kʊ-kʊ-n-keet-a ʊ-n-na gw-a n-gwina bo ba-lɪ pa-katɪ pa-m-ɪɪsi bi-kw-end-a ɪ-n-gwina jɪ-lɪnkw-and-a ʊ-kʊ-lɪl-a a-ma-soosi
trs: \lq When monkey had mounted Crocodile, going to see Crocodile's mother, when they were travelling in the middle of the water, Crocodile started to cry.

src: po ɪ-n-gwina jɪ-lɪnkʊ-gomok-a mpaka kʊ-m-balɪ kʊ-lw-ɪsi
trs: \lq Crocodile returned to the shore of the river.
\lq Monkey told the other monkeys.
\lq He climbed up a mango tree.

src: a-lɪnkʊ-jɪ-koolel-a ɪ-n-gwina ʊkʊtɪ jɪ-j-e kɪfuki paa-si
trs: \lq He called crocodile so that it would be close below.
\lq He told the other monkeys.
\lq They started throwing mangoes at Crocodile.

src: fyobeene ɪ-n-gwina ʊ-m̩-bɪlɪ gw-ake gʊ-ka-j-a n-nunu, paapo ba-a-jɪ-tuuny-ile fiijo
trs: \lq That is why, as for Crocodile, its body is not beautiful, because they threw at it hard.
\lq It started to run, to run into the water.
\lq The friendship between Crocodile and Monkey came to an end.
\lq This is the story.

src: po tʊ-kʊ-tɪ kalʊlʊ na nsyɪsyɪ ba-a-lɪ ba-manyaani fiijo
trs: \lq We say, Hare and Skunk were good friends.
\lq They went together wherever they went.

src: po leelo ii-sikʊ lɪ-mo kalʊlʊ na nsyɪsyɪ ba-a-bʊʊk-ile n-kʊ-fwɪm-a
trs: \lq So one day Hare and Skunk went to hunt.
\lq  When they were hunting they caught a guinea fowl.
\lq They were very happy.
\lq They went home.

src: bo ba-fik-ile kʊ-ka-aja ba-a-peeny-ile ii-kanga lɪ-la
trs: \lq When they arrived home, they removed the feathers from that guinea fowl.
\lq They removed feathers and removed feathers.
\lq They began to roast it over fire.
\lq They sat together and sat together.
\lq Then Skunk became tired.
\lq He began to doze.

src: po bo i-kʊ-sipʊk-a, bo a-gon-ile ʊ-tʊ-lo po kalʊlʊ a-aly-eg-ile ɪɪ-nyama j-oosa
trs: ‎‎As he was dozing, as he was asleep, Hare took all the meat.
He ate it up, he ate it up.

src: bo i-kʊ-lembʊk-a nsyɪsyɪ a-lɪnkw-ag-a kalʊlʊ a-l-iile j-oosa ɪɪ-nyama
trs: When Skunk woke up, he found that Hare had eaten all of the meat.
Skunk was very angry.
\lq  ‎‎Another day they went to sleep.
\lq Skunk also went.
\lq He went and searched for leaves.

src: a-al-iis-ile na=a-ma-ani ga-la bo a-gon-ile ʊ-tʊ-lo kalʊlʊ
trs: \lq He came with those leaves, while Hare was asleep.
\lq He covered him [with the leaves].

src: po bo a-n-kupɪkiile a-a-lond-ile ɪ-n-gili, bo kalʊlʊ a-gon-ile ʊ-tʊ-lo
trs: \lq When he had covered him, he searched for a stick, while Hare was asleep.
\lq Then Skunk hit and hit and hit and hit him.
\lq He hit him.
\lq He ran outside.
\lq He went outside.
\lq Then Hare woke up.

src: po leelo po ii-sikʊ lɪ-mo ba-a-bʊʊk-ile b-oosa kʊ-kʊ-mog-a ɪ-n-goma
trs: \lq Then one day they went together to dance to the Ngoma drums.

src: po bo ba-fik-ile pa-la kalʊlʊ a-aly-eg-ile ɪ-n-goma
trs: \lq When they arrived there, Hare took a drum.
\lq Skunk listened.

src: po bo a-bɪɪk-ile paa-si ɪ-n-goma j-oope nsyɪsyɪ eeg-a ɪ-n-goma
trs: \lq When he [Hare] had put the drum on the ground, Skunk also took the drum.
\lq Hare listend.

src: po bo i-kʊ-pɪlɪkɪsy-a po a-a-sumwike kalʊlʊ
trs: \lq As he was listening, Hare stood up.
\lq They grasped each other's bodies.

\lq Holding each other,\footnote{This use of \textit{kolaana} is the only attested use of a bare verb stem that does not serve as an imperative.} holding each other, holding each other, they held each other.
\lq Hare grasped Skunk.
\lq He squeezed around his [Skunk's] snout.
\lq He began to squeeze around his snout.

src: po j-oope nsyɪsyɪ a-a-kol-ile ɪ-m-bʊlʊkʊtʊ sy-a kalʊlʊ
trs: \lq Also Skunk grasped Hare's ears.
\lq He started to pull, to pull.
\lq They fought and fought and fought.
\lq Then Dog came.
\lq They released each other.
\lq So now Skunk is flat at the snout.
\lq As for Hare, his ears are long.
\lq The custom of dancing.
\lq There were the people of old times, the ancestors.
\lq They had the Penenga drum.
\lq This drum was called Penenga.
\lq As to its custom, they danced much.
\lq For the dancing they dressed well.
\lq They bathed well.
\lq Some combed their hair.
\lq It stood much.
\lq They combed it.
\lq They called it Fibwesi [hairstyle].
\lq Some combed it.
\lq They parted it.
\lq They also used whips for dancing.

src: bo ba-kaalɪ ʊ-kw-and-a ʊ-kʊ-mog-a ba-a-fwal-aga ɪ-my-enda ɪ-my-elu, pamo a-ma-golole a-m-eelu
trs: \lq Before starting to dance, they would put on white clothes, or white sheets.
\lq They were nicely embroidered.
\lq They [were so clean that it] appeared as if a person never held them at all.

src: looli leelo ngɪmba a-ba-ndʊ bi-kʊ-kol-a kʊʊ-nongwa j-aa kʊ-tɪ a-ba-ndʊ ba-la ba-a-j-aga b-iifyʊsi fiijo
trs: \lq But truely, behold, people hold them because those people were very neat.

src: po lɪnga bo ba-lɪ pa-kʊ-mog-a ba-a-mog-aga
trs: \lq When people were dancing, they danced.
\lq They tilted to one side.
\lq When they turned, they turned to the [other] side.
\lq Sometimes they would run to the front.

src: halafu lɪnga ba-luluutiile po ba-a-mog-aga fiijo
trs: \lq When they [women] had ululuated, they [men] danced much.
\lq They also beated the drum hard.

src: po lɪnga ba-kʊb-ile bo ʊ-lʊ, lɪnga jɪ-lɪ kw-Itete kʊ-la, j-iis-aga kʊ-fik-a mpaka kʊ-no
trs: \lq When they beated it like this, if it was in Itete over there, it [noise] would come to reach this place here.

src: po tw-a-many-aga ʊkʊtɪ kʊ-la ʊ-bw-ite bʊ-kol-eene ʊ-bw-a kʊ-moga
trs: \lq Then we would know that a dancing competition was being held.
\lq The custom is what?, it is very enjoyable.
\lq People crowded there to look.

src: kʊʊ-nongwa j-aa kʊ-tɪ fi-ki, ba-a-mog-aga kanunu fiijo
trs: \lq For what reason, [because] they danced very well.

src: lɪnga ba-lɪ pa-kʊ-sanuk-a kʊʊ-nyuma kʊ-no k-oope ba-a-kyakyatɪl-aga fiijo bʊno$\sim$bʊ-no
trs: \lq When they were turning back there they would move quickly back and forth like this.

src: po lɪnga ba-mog-ile kʊ-lʊ-mogo lw-abo a-ba-ndʊ ba-a-hobok-aga fiijo
trs: \lq When they danced, people rejoiced much at their dance.

src: kʊʊ-nongawa j-aa kʊ-ti fi-ndʊ fi-ki, jʊ-la ʊ-gw-a kʊ-kʊb-a j-oope a-kʊb-ile kanunu, a-ba-a kʊ-mog-a ba-mog-ile kanunu
trs: \lq For what reason, [because] the drum player had played well, the dancers had danced well.

src: po bo n̩di sisii$\sim$si po lo lw-iho lw-ɪtʊ twe ba-Nyakyusa
trs: \lq So this is the custom of us, the Nyakyusa people.

src: ii-penenga ɪ-lɪ ba-a-b-oot-aga n=ʊ-kʊ-b-oot-a lɪnga pamo si-li=mo ɪɪ-ʃerehe
trs: \lq As for that drum, they invited and invited people when there was a celebration.
\lq So they went to dance.

src: po palɪ sisii$\sim$si si-lɪ m̩-bʊ-pimba, m̩-bʊ-pimba
trs: \lq So this is it in short, in short.
\lq It has finished right here.
